title: Temperature & Humidity Control for White's Tree Frogs
author: Habitat Builder Team
excerpt: White's Tree Frog�specific temperature targets, humidity management, probe placement, and why you probably don't need misters. Keep these Australian frogs in warm, DRY conditions.
description: White's Tree Frog�specific temperature targets, humidity management, probe placement, and why you probably don't need misters. Keep these Australian frogs in warm, DRY conditions.

content.text: White's Tree Frogs are Australian semi-arid species adapted to warm, DRY conditions�not high humidity like many keepers assume. Proper temperature control and LOW humidity (30�40%) are the two pillars of their care. Avoid misters and foggers; a large water dish and ventilation are all you need.

rows: Ambient temp
Warm zone at top (85-88�F), cooler below. Critical nighttime drop mimics wild fluctuations.
Basking spot
Warm zone at top for basking and digestion. Essential for metabolic health.
Humidity
CRITICAL: Semi-arid species. Stay DRY. Never exceed 50% sustained.
Surface moisture
Mostly dry
Lightly damp
Substrate should not be soggy; top layer must dry out by morning

content.content: ?? COMMON MISTAKE: Keeping humidity above 50% promotes bacterial blooms, respiratory infections, and mold. White's Tree Frogs thrive in warm, DRY Australian conditions. Do NOT use misters, foggers, manual misting unless required.

content.heading: Temperature Probe Placement for White's Tree Frogs

items: Place the main thermometer probe at mid-height on the warm side of the enclosure (where the heat lamp is).
Place a second probe at the top of the enclosure to monitor the warm basking zone (aim for 85-88�F).
Position the hygrometer probe at mid-height as well, away from direct heat sources and water dishes.
Monitor for one week after setup; adjust heat lamp height or wattage to hit 75-88�F ambient and 88�F basking.
The nighttime drop to 70-75�F is CRITICAL for metabolism and digestion�use a thermostat-controlled heat lamp or lower the temperature at night.

content.text: White's Tree Frogs are NOT tropical rainforest frogs�they are Australian semi-arid frogs that need LOW humidity (30�40%). Many keepers make the mistake of over-humidifying. A large water dish and natural room ventilation are all you need.

items: Primary moisture source: A large, shallow water dish (minimum 4�6 inches diameter). Change water every 2�3 days.
NO misters or foggers: Absolutely avoid them. They raise humidity too high, promote bacterial growth, and cause respiratory infections.
Ventilation is key: Use a mesh top or partial screen to allow air exchange. This naturally keeps humidity in the 30�40% range.
Substrate: Keep the top layer mostly dry; substrate should never be soggy or waterlogged.
If humidity creeps above 50%: Increase airflow by opening vents, removing obstacles, or upgrading to a fully screened top.

content.content: The Golden Rule: If your room has 40�50% humidity and the enclosure has a screen top with a water dish, you're done. No misting needed. Your frogs are happier in a dry setup than a humid one.

items: Move enclosure to coolest room in the house (basement ideal).
Use portable AC unit or fan to cool the room�NEVER blow air directly on the enclosure.
Emergency cooling: Place frozen water bottles wrapped in towels OUTSIDE the enclosure to radiate cool air. Replace every 4-6 hours.
Reduce heat lamp wattage or raise fixture higher to lower basking temp.
Monitor closely: If ambient exceeds 90�F for extended periods, frogs can overheat. Signs include gaping mouth, lethargy, seeking water constantly.
Increase heat lamp wattage (75-100W) to maintain 75-88�F ambient.
Use ceramic heat emitter (CHE) at night to maintain nighttime temps at 70-75�F minimum.
Add insulation: Place foam board or reflective insulation on back/sides of enclosure (NOT front or top�blocks ventilation).
Use thermostat to prevent overheating�critical when boosting heat sources.
Check water dish more frequently�heat sources will increase evaporation.

content.content: Thermostat Recommendations: Use a proportional thermostat (not on/off). Recommended models: Herpstat, Vivarium Electronics VE-200, or Inkbird ITC-308. Set to target 82-85�F daytime, 70-72�F nighttime.

rows: Humidity above 50% (too wet)
Poor ventilation, excess misting, standing water, overly moist substrate
Open vents wider, remove standing water, stop all misting, reduce substrate moisture. High humidity = respiratory infections.
Humidity below 25% (too dry)
Small water dish, room too dry, excessive ventilation
Add larger water dish (6-8" diameter), ensure it's clean and accessible. Partially cover 25% of mesh top with acrylic to trap moisture from dish.
Temperature below 75�F (too cold)
Insufficient heat source, low room temp, heat lamp too far from enclosure
Upgrade heat lamp wattage (60-100W depending on size), lower fixture closer to basking spot, use thermostat for consistency. Ambient must stay 75-88�F.
No warm zone above 85�F (basking too cool)
Heat lamp too far away, insufficient wattage, blocked by decor
Move heat lamp closer to top of enclosure, increase wattage slightly (75-100W), position directly over basking perch. Aim for 88�F at top.
No nighttime drop below 75�F
Heat lamp running 24/7, no thermostat control
Use thermostat-controlled heat lamp that dims/turns off at night. The 70-75�F nighttime drop is essential for digestion and metabolic health.
Frogs hiding constantly, not basking
High humidity causing stress, temperature instability, inadequate temp gradient
Verify daytime ambient 75-88�F, basking zone 88�F, nighttime drop to 70-75�F. Lower humidity to 30-40%. Increase ventilation.
